awd_titl_txt: EAGER/Collaborative Research: CRYO: Engineering Atomically Thin Magnetic Materials for Efficient Solid-State Cooling at Cryogenic Temperatures
awd_abstract_narration:
Solid-state cooling schemes can potentially circumvent the use of increasingly expensive and scarce He3 in cryogenic refrigeration below 1K. He3 is required in almost all current commercial ultralow refrigeration approaches used in the operation of quantum computers, sensors and other new technologies. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project will advance the fundamental understanding of the heat-release process in ultrathin magnetic materials and thus provide the guidance to manufacture magnetic quantum materials for next-generation solid-state refrigeration, promoting the fundamental physics of heat transport and cooling on the nanoscale and aid in the development of new classes of cooling technologies. When certain magnetic materials are magnetized at low temperatures, the removal of the magnetic field leads to the randomization of once magnetically ordered domains within material. During the formation or ordering of these of multiple magnetic domains, thermal energy in the material is absorbed by domains to reorient their magnetizations, thereby leading to temperature drop (i.e., cooling). Atomically thin magnetic materials can be engineered to control and enhance these processes and thus could open up unexplored opportunities for emerging cooling devices. This effort will support the fundamental research to understand the modifications to these magnetic quantum materials to enable efficient solid-state cooling, particularly at cryogenic temperatures such as below 1K. The technology to be developed can mitigate the existing challenges associated with the worldwide shortage of helium. High-school students and students of traditionally underrepresented groups will be exposed to the comprehensive training including quantum materials fabrication, materials modelling and simulation, cryogenic hardware engineering, and low-temperature experiments. This research will help to equip these students with necessary knowledge and expertise as the workforce for the future quantum science and engineering.

The magnetocaloric effect holds a great potential for solid-state refrigeration. However, the magnetocaloric effect in traditional materials is not strong, but it can be enhanced if a structural phase change can be concomitant with the magnetic phase transition. However, inducing these first-order phase transitions have conventionally relied on the compositional modification of the material through scarce and expensive rare-earth-elements based compounds. This research proposes to overcome the knowledge gap in the understanding and control of two-dimensional magnetic materials for an enhanced magnetocaloric effect. The research team will apply first-principles materials simulations to understand the magnetism-structure relationship in two-dimensional magnets, employ experimental synthesis and processing to engineer two-dimensional magnets, and apply magnetoelectric and magneto-optical characterizations to quantify the resultant magnetic properties. The research will elucidate the fundamental relationship between local atomic structures, crystalline structures and magnetic properties of emerging two-dimensional magnets, which could provide useful guidance for the design and optimization of low-dimensional magnetic structures for clean cooling technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
3He-dilution refrigerators constitute the predominant cooling technique for quantum-based scientific research and device development below 1 Kelvin (e.g., computing, sensing, and quantum transport). Helium as a light/tiny molecule easily escapes into space and thus is nonrenewable, and furthermore, the 3He isotope is extremely rare (with a natural isotopic abundance at 0.00014%). Searching for new cooling materials/techniques therefore becomes an urgent need for the envisioned quantum-technology revolution.

This one-year project spans 01/01/2023-12/31/2023, focusing on the experimental exploration of the magnetocaloric effect of two-dimensional (2D) layered magnets for the potential development of solid-state refrigeration that is suitable for < 1 Kelvin condition. Given the magnetocaloric effect of magnetic materials reaches the maximum at their Curie temperatures (below which the nonmagnetic materials become ferromagnetic), one focus of this research is to engineer the Curie temperatures of 2D magnets to about 1 Kelvin. The team adopted different approaches including chemical treatment (e.g., oxidization and alloy engineering) and heterostructure contact (e.g., ferroelectrics) to engineer 2D magnet properties, including their fundamental parameters such as exchange interaction and magnetic anisotropy and the manifested observables such as magnetic coercivity and Curie temperature.

Specifically, the team found that (1) the alloy engineering can systematically tune the anisotropy and Curie temperature of Cr2SixGe(2-x)Te6 [1], (2) the oxidants and atomic layer deposition of oxides on the 2D magnet Fe5GeTe2 can even convert a few layers of Fe5GeTe2 to antiferromagnetic [2], leading to the observation of exchange bias between ferromagnetic Fe5GeTe2 and antiferromagnetic oxidized-Fe5GeTe2, (3) a few layers of Fe3GeT2 can alter the properties of the neighboring 2D magnet Fe3GeTe2 in "homostructure" [3], leading to altered anisotropy and coercivity, and (4) ferroelectrics such as P(VDF-TrFE) can affect the magnetic anisotropy and coercivity of the neighboring 2D magnet Cr2Ge2Te6 in a non-volatile manner [4]. Two Ph.D. students and one postdoc led these sub-projects with a few collaborating students in the PI's and collaborators' research groups. These students and postdocs got trained in the knowledge of 2D magnetism and expertise of heterostructure construction, atomic layer deposition, device fabrication, and magneto-optical characterizations. An undergraduate student of the underrepresented group participated in this project as the research intern for a semester to work on 2D material preparation and heterostructure construction. 

 

[1] T. Xie, S. Liang, S. Deitemyer, Q. Wang, T. Zhou, I. Žutić, X. Zhang, D. Yuan, X. Zhang, C. Gong, "Compositional engineering of magnetic anisotropy in Cr2SixGe2-xTe6." Materials Today Electronics 7, 100081 (2023).

[2] J. Liang, S. Liang, T. Xie, A. F. May, T. Ersevim, Q. Wang, H. Ahn, C. Lee, X. Zhang, J.-P. Wang, M. A. McGuire, M. Ouyang, C. Gong, "Facile integration of giant exchange bias in Fe5GeTe2/oxide heterostructures by atomic layer deposition." Physical Review Materials 7, 014008 (2023).

[3] S. Liang, J. Liang, J. C. Kotsakidis, H. S. Arachchige, D. Mandrus, A. L. Friedman, C. Gong, "New coercivities and Curie temperatures emerged in van der Waals homostructures." Physical Review Materials 7, L061001 (2023).

[4] S. Liang, T. Xie, N. A. Blumenschein, T. Zhou, T. Ersevim, Z. Song, J. Liang, M. A. Susner, B. S. Conner, S.-J. Gong, J.-P. Wang, M. Ouyang, I. Žutić, A. L. Friedman, X. Zhang, C. Gong, "Small-voltage multiferroic control of two-dimensional magnetic insulators." Nature Electronics 6, 199-205 (2023).
